newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Former Filipino rebel named development chief.
newsitem.headline: Former Filipino rebel named development chief.

text.p: Philippine President Fidel Ramos on Tuesday appointed former Moslem rebel chief Nur Misuari as head of a controversial body to supervise development in 14 provinces in the southern Philippines.
As chairman of the Southern Philippine Council for Peace and Development (SPCPD), Misuari will have a major say in drawing up economic programmes in an area dominated by Christians.

The creation of the SPCPD with Misuari as head is part of a peace deal signed last month between Manila and the Moro National Liberation Front (MNLF) ending a 24-year revolt for Moslem self-rule in the southern Mindanao region.
Misuari, the head of the MNLF, is also serving concurrently as governor of a semi-autonomous region comprising four Moslem provinces after being elected to the post in recent polls.
Under the deal, the SPCPD will serve as forerunner of a wider autonomy area composed of the four Moslem provinces and others voting to join it in a plebiscite to be held in three years.
Nine Christian politicians have asked the Supreme Court to declare the SPCPD unconstitutional, saying it would lead to Moslem minority rule in largely Christian provinces and cities.
Ramos said the court had not issued any order declaring the SPCPD illegal, thus clearing the way for Misuari's appointment as its chairman.
The country's five million Moslem minority regard Mindanao as their ancestral homeland although they are now outnumbered 3-to-1 in the area by Christians.
Manila is holding exploratory talks with another Moslem insurgent group, the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF), to try to reach a separate peace deal.
The MILF, although smaller than the mainstream MNLF, is considered by the military to be more dangerous because it wants to set up an Islamic state in the southern islands.
